newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: SAfrica quid pro quo asset swaps hit snags - report.
newsitem.headline: SAfrica quid pro quo asset swaps hit snags - report.

text.p: The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission has ruled against the legality of quid pro quo asset swaps between South Africa and the United States, the Business Day newspaper reported on Thursday.
It said the move could unscramble some of the 19.4 billion rand in approved asset swap arrangements.

A quid pro quo asset swap occurs where the foreign party involved in the transaction is also the South African institution's foreign asset manager, a situation which results in reciprocal management fees for the U.S. party.

The commission's ruling followed a request by Templeton South Africa, a subsidiary of U.S.-based, global fund management company Templeton Asset Management, to grant an order exempting it from U.S. legislation prohibiting quid pro quo swaps, the report said.
Templeton chief executive John Phillips said on Wednesday that the Securities and Exchange Commission had turned down the request.
Phillips said the events had "vindicated our decision to abstain from entering into asset swaps of this nature pending further clarification."
